I was pretty much on the bandwagon with this movie, mostly because of the devoted effort that the animators have worked on from Rocketsheep Studio's last film from 2016, Saving Sally, a beautifully made film mixing animated and live-action elements in a seamless polish, only to be pulled down with a standard plot and intolerable characters. So even with my skewed expectations for this film, I still do hope that this would fare better, and...It does, but it does not at the same time. So I may as well start out with the cons before the pros, and these have to do with the story and themes itself and how the tone can clash with the animation. Given that it's rated 18, the themes that it tackles do fit well, but how they are executed is in poor taste, which does remind me of how Saving Sally executes its own mature themes, but at least this film gives these themes a bit more room for discussion, even if it's dealt with in a sour, and sometimes questionable manner. The story is simple yet dramatic and can hit some good moments. I just wished it was a bit longer and does not cut through dramatic scene to dramatic scene so quickly, which made the resolution and ending so spotty, unsatisfying, and utterly rushed. The overall tone can clash with the animation in a consistent way, as some scenes do not mesh well with the hyperbolic nature of the animation, which can make some of the melodramatic scenes to be unfit and oddly uncomfortable with the cinematic and energetic flow of the animation.Pushing the flaws aside, I will say that the animation is excellent all throughout. Smooth, expressive, and gives the characters a lot of personality. The backgrounds are detailed with anthro versions of real-life brands, mottos, and references which gives more attention to detail to the movie. And the performances for the most part are also in their A-game as well, especially Angelica Panganiban.Even despite my mixed feelings for this movie, I still do want to convince everyone to watch the film, because if the film managed to succeed in its streaming sales, then that would determine how many animated films would go down the line in the years to come. And hey, with the animation this good, who wouldn't be excited for more locally animated films such as this one?

Even with all the controversy behind it recently, we want "Hayop Ka!" ("You Animal!") to succeed. The film is a technical marvel with its animation and is truly a showcase on what our local artists can do. But nothing can save it from its very simple and one-sided characters and narrative - that have no redeeming values or whatsoever. Nimfa Dimaano (Angelica Panganiban) is a pretty cat who works as a perfume sales lady at a department store. Her boyfriend is Roger (Robin Padilla) who works as a janitor and already happy and satisfied with his standing in life. But Nimfa wants more and when she meets I√±igo Villanueva (Sam Milby), a super rich business dog, their chemistry ignites. Who will Nimfa choose? Roger‚Äôs unending love or I√±igo‚Äôs unending riches?Taking years to make, it seemed like much of the effort in creating "Hayop Ka!" was put into crafting its world of parody. If you're a Filipino viewer then every scene will be oozing with inside jokes that it was actually as amusing as the animation itself. Speaking of the animation, this is the strongest asset for "Hayop Ka!". The colorful and vibrant environments and palette make every scene stand out and the 2D animation had the perfect mix of feeling nostalgic and modern at the same time. The voice acting was good but not great. While the voice actors themselves handled the script well, there's just this feeling that the visuals and audio didn't match up 100%. Unfortunately, the film had poorly-written characters and narrative. It was too simple to the point that the characters themselves were one-sided and extremely flawed. The characters do "bad things" and there's little chance for them to redeem themselves given the film's running time of 98 minutes. We understand that this is a raunchy comedy but putting non-redeemable characters just for the sake of being in tone with its theme was a bad decision in our opinion. Overall though, "Hayop Ka!" at least had excellent comedy and visuals that will make you laugh - just don't expect to get anything else from the experience. Story and writing: 2.5/5Animation: 4/5Characters and voice acting: 3.5/5Overall score: 10/15Rating: Decent (3.33/5)Song: "Love Me Like You Do" by Ellie Goulding (from "50 Shades of Grey") - youtu.be/AJtDXIazrMoBeing Singaporean, it's such a pleasant surprise that Southeast Asian animation is getting better and better each year given that it's a very small industry in the region, even in 2020. I got to be honest, 2020 is the year where the small and low-budget animated movies managed to be at times on par with the mainstream giants. Hayop Ka (or You Animal), from the Philippines' Rocketsheep Studios (who also produced the unique hybrid movie "Saving Sally") should be included on that list.The story parodies on classic Filippino soap oprea tropes, in that it's a love triangle between a saleslady, her janitor boyfriend and a rich businessman whom she feel in love with the first time they encountered each other. One of the best things about the story is that it's one of the funniest animated movies of the year. The amount of animal-related puns, innuendos and sexual tensions justify the M18 rating there, but it also sacrificed the cohesion and flow of the love triangle, an absolute shame given that it's the writing that mainly let the whole movie down (also, a little bit too many storylines to cover in such a short frame). Still, for their first animated movie attempt, the story is still enjoyable to a certain extent.But, let's talk about the most surprising element of the movie: the animation. This is easily well animated. I know I prefer 2D animation to 3D CGI, but for an animated movie made in the Philippines, this is a solid attempt! There are moments where the colours are a little bit flat, but when the animation gets dynamic, it shows the full potential of its animation and we rarely get this type of animation anymore. Kudos to the guys at Rocketsheep for such great animation.As for characters, most of the main cast are full realised, although given its 73-minute runtime, some of the development felt rushed. I feel for the main character Nimfa (voiced by Angelica Panganiban) as she struggled to keep her affection with the rich businessman a secret as well as the two main male leads. If the story is a letdown, the entertaining characters did not.I will give Hayop Ka credit for one thing: they should not be underestimated when it comes to low budget animated movies that came out in 2020, especially when it's easily one of the most entertaining low budget animated movies of 2020. It's currently available in most Asian countries that has Netflix, so if you can't wait to support Filippino animation but you are outside Asia, do keep a lookout for its release in other countries on Netflix. Trust me, Hayop Ka is a great surprise, but I truly wish for 10 to 15 more minutes of this great animated and furry parody of typical Filippino soap opreas.

From the creators of "Saving Sally" comes this Filipino adult-animated film that is a visual marvel on its own right. Animation vendor Rocketsheep Studios created a visually stunning animation with a consistent style that explodes onscreen. Plus, the visual gags and colorful sequences make it stand out.Where it falls is on its story that manages to be frustratingly unoriginal and unconsciously misogynistic. While the core narrative was inspired from an actual caller story, it just rings of the flaws of typical Filipino rom-coms. And it only made the character of Nimfa Dimaano really stale.Speaking of, while she did a decent job, Angelica Panganiban is no voice actor when doing Nimfa. The only ones to stand out in the voiceover department are Empoy Marquez as Inigo's jolly chauffeur Larry/Jerry (insert stolen "Parks & Rec" joke here), Arci Munoz as Nimfa's best friend Jherelyn and Piolo Pascual as a radio DJ. But they cannot get over the fact that they play stock characters.Overall, "Hayop Ka!" excels in the animation department but settles that with a generic and flawed story. Other than criticizing Robon Padilla, naysayers can at least acknowledge its animation potential.

SPOILERS all the way1) Since I watched the film with friends (through Netflix Party/Teleparty), there was entertainment in its crude dialogue and spotting out several puns, even the corny ones like in the police station: "We Serve and Protecc" but it became apparent, around halfway through the run time, the film has nothing else to offer.2) Inconsistent characterization with ML (Huskie). At first, he was portrayed as an arrogant rich snob by buying a whole restaurant for failing to honor his reservation. Then, for the most part, he was actually kind. Not only to the FL but to everyone. His character came back near the end where he says "Girls no need to fight. You can share me". But at that point it was already a hopeless case. 3) There are some potential dramatic scenes but somewhat downplayed by execution. Example near the end where the FL finds that her sister is already a parent . There is no apparent build-up. It escalated quickly, in this case, to a cat fight, which to be honest lost its effectiveness. A sample of a proper build-up is that classic "Wag Mo Akong Ma Terry Terry" scene. In this scene, there was also a beat of the sister returning a money FL sent through the years. I like this beat. It gives the sister a bit more depth that she is not solely living off FL's allowance and is actually serious about earning her keep. But it was just downplayed, as if it didn't happen. Like FL didn't even recognize this. It would have been nice if sister put up a fight with FL. It was all too one-sided. Also in this scene, I'm 50/50 on this. They made a joke after the dramatic scene. Can't recall it properly but it includes FL saying you are too young. You don't have breast. I might even have to breast feed your baby. Then FL's mother rebuts, don't worry I can still breastfeed while she massages her breast. Like whuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuut I mean per se its funny, it's just a bit out of place.4) At its current state, the writing is just an excuse to make the film rather than the basis of the film. This is a shame because the script has a potential dramatic core. I'm referring to FL discovering she is (A) pregnant not with her current BF but with her recent ex, (B) who happens to now be with her best friend and all the while (C) her sister is also pregnant. Rocketsheep Studios needs to stop hiring shitty writers. This is not going to convince a lot of people to support animation, if the thing that they're animating is crude, disgusting and reminiscent of the problems plaguing local entertainment.This movie is an amalgamation of everything familiar and stereotypical of an afternoon at a local TV channel: homewreckers, cheaters, exaggerated rich-poor conversations, and all the things regular viewers across the country seem to swoon over on the daily. The folks over at Rocketsheep seem to think that this makes for a passable idea in the animation department. Did it work? Yes. Do I like it? FUCK NO.If the goal of this cartoonish re-imagining of a soap opera is to drown it in cutely-drawn pastel-style animation interspersed with clear homages to GMA-7's Astig Authority (afternoon segments where international anime series are dubbed in Tagalog for local audiences), then congratulations, they're going to successfully hook in the support. But to explicitly juxtapose this advocacy of creative animation with the morally replete narratives of your average Philippine soap is just deplorable. What they're doing here, is making a statement that the only way to somehow succeed and get more support from everyone is to just get what already works for the masses. This isn't something I look forward to if the future of the industry is really dictated by the preposterous concept that is this movie.Put it this way, the story can just as easily be inserted as a real-life adaptation in the hands of grubby network executives. If independent studios like Rocketsheep are already behaving in the same manner when it comes to advocating the #SupportLocal mentality, then we have a big problem here.And for the love of god, DO NOT TELL ME THIS BULLSHIT IS SATIRE. I wasn‚Äôt planning on writing reviews when i made a letterboxd account. I just wanted to lurk, read reviews, check out people‚Äôs lists, stalk user profiles and yes, read every single review to every movie I directed because i like crying myself to sleep at night. But after watching hayop ka and reading the reviews here, i was compelled to write something. Because i don‚Äôt get why people hate it so much. For me, it‚Äôs a dark comedy that tackles realities of class and socio-economic disparity in the Philippines. Nimfa‚Äôs problem is simple: she‚Äôs poor. She has to break her back working as a saleslady to pay for her sister‚Äôs tuition and pay rent, she has pares to look forward to during special occasions because that‚Äôs all she and her boyfriend could afford, she can‚Äôt even go to a motel for some sexy time. This isn‚Äôt necessary a problem except for one thing: Nimfa is dissatisfied. She is not happy with her situation. She wants more. But what can she do? She didn‚Äôt graduate and it‚Äôs very likely that she‚Äôll be a saleslady forever. So can you really blame her when she ‚Äúfalls‚Äù for I√±igo? A handsome rich guy who showers her with attention? If you were in her situation, wouldn‚Äôt you? I would. So she makes one bad choice after another. Should we hate her for it? What would we rather see? Tanggapin nalang niya yung buhay niyang ganun? Ok lang yang pares ghorl masarap naman. Beauty in poverty ganun? She sees a way out, and she grabs it. I am not entirely happy with her choice but i understand why she did it. Eh sa sawa nang maging mahirap ‚Äôyung tao e. The bad choices that Nimfa makes are greatly influenced by her circumstances, circumstances that are forced upon her because she is poor. Yes cliche. Yes lagi nalang mahirap/mayaman storyline but maybe there‚Äôs a reason why the boss-katulong trope(the powerful loving the powerless) works so well in our country. Maybe it‚Äôs because most of us Filipinos still see that as the only means of escape.And hayop ka lays bare that truth: If you‚Äôre poor, falling in love out of economic need is very much a reality. This truth is prevalent in our narratives, even if they aren‚Äôt explicitly stated. Some top of mind examples are Laida Magtalas falling in love with sir Miggy(A very special love) or Maya with Sir Chief(be careful with my heart). Fuck i‚Äôm oldüò≠üò≠ The difference in hayop ka is that it does away with romantics and explicitly states, with ice cold pragmatism: I am in love with you because I am poor, because you are my best option to escape this life. It‚Äôs tragic how in the world presented in hayop ka, genuine romantic love is a privilege for the rich.And another note, can i just say that the art direction is fucking gorgeous. Making drawings move is an expensive and time-consuming affair and you have to find ways to get your point across in as few frames as possible. Hayop ka borrows some techniques from Japanese animation which it uses brilliantly and comically. Future animations will surely use this film as a reference.-1 half star lang pala for too much sexual jokes. Not that im offended or anything and i‚Äôm totally fine with women exhibiting the same sexual libido and desire as men, it‚Äôs just that there were too many and most of them weren‚Äôt funny. -1 half star ulit for the ending with empoy the frog. Liongoren's Hayop Ka! is a tongue-in-cheek and provocative 2D animated film seen from the perspective of proletariat catwoman Nimfa Dimaano, as she finds herself slowly loosening her morals in desperate exchange of economic indemnity. The film is deceptively simple, but functions intelligently to provide a scathing representation of the cyclical, problematic lives of the working class Filipino: their desensitisation to the methods they cling onto for their own economic benefit, the internalized sexist and especially misogynistic paradigm that remains hegemonic among both Filipino men and women, and how all this disturbingly becomes the mundanity of everyday life in a third-world country. Moreover, although the narrative might simply appear as an animated rehash of what has plagued local TV for years, it cleverly utilizes these teleserye tropes to construct a sociological examination on capitalism's destruction to society; more specifically, to the Filipinos that belong to the lower end of the social strata. Past the painfully realistic reconstruction of the plight of the working class in film, the portrayal on the bourgeoisie is also excellently handled; they're cruel and selfish, despite the already comfortable lives that they live. Hence, the anthropomorphism of these animals becomes a clever display of how capitalism has made literal animals out of us‚Äî easily succumbing to carnal desires and almost devoid of empathy.Aside from the thematic complexity of Hayop Ka!, the meticulously beautiful animation is extremely noteworthy as well. Sadly, this film has been misread by most of its viewers‚Äî its intelligent writing and thematic complexity ignored due to its vulgar, yet realistically absurd humor. Needless to say, Hayop Ka! is up there thematically, and can even suffice to be the lovechild of two classics that eloquently critique capitalism: last year's Parasite, and 1962 Mexican film The Exterminating Angel. Definitely one of the year's best!

You have no idea the effort I put in to actually watch this, and I can't really recommend it to anybody else - an animated film with spot-on Cartoon Network aesthetics, relentless sex jokes, and a setting (Metro Manila) where I spent a lot of my formative years. Jeepnies!) and several I forgot (the wire mesh displays for drinks, holy shit!) The animation and design are lovely, but are helped by some truly genius visual comedy and meme references. And for as selfish as our protagonists are, I thought their motives made sense. The story may go full soap opera, but at least it's never boring.From what I've seen on Letterboxd, most of the reviews compliment the film's look but criticize it for perpetuating tropes of clasism and misogyny that are apparently well-represented in Filipino media. For all the time I spent living there, I never really watched much that was locally made, and am only vaguely familiar with the craziness that has been going on with the current government.As a piece of satire, I thought this worked. But, I'm also not the smartest guy I know.
